title-group.article-title: Northrop Frye: The Consolation of Criticism

ref.mixed-citation: Northrop Frye, Anatomy of Criticism: Four Essays (1957; Princeton: Princeton UP, 1973).
Richard Stingle, "Frye, Northrop," The Johns Hopkins Guide to Literary Theory & Criticism, ed. Michael Gro- den and Martin Kreiswirth (Baltimore, London: The Johns Hopkins UP, 1994) 317-21
Alvin A. Lee, "Frye, Northrop," Encyclopedia of Contemporary Literary Theory: Approaches, Scholars, Terms, ed. Irena R. Makaryk (Toronto, Buffalo: U of Toronto P, 1993) 324-6

Edward W. Said, "Reflections on Recent American 'Left' Literary Criticism," The Ques- tion of Textuality: Strategies of Reading in Contemporary American Criticism, ed. William V. Spanos, Paul A. Bov√©, and Daniel O'Hara (Bloomington: Indiana UP, 1982) 11-30, here 18.
Mieke Bal, Narratology: Introduction to the Theory of Narrative, second edition (To- ronto, Buffalo: U of Toronto P, 1997).
Seymour Chatman, Story and Discourse: Narrative Struc- ture in Fiction and Film (Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell UP, 1978)

Frye in two pages: "Why four types and six phases rather than six types and four phases, or ten types and ten phases? In the titles the mythoi are equated with four seasons, comedy with spring, romance with summer, tragedy with autumn, irony-satire with winter. But there are other numbers equally fraught with significance-the three of the holy trinity, the seven vices and virtues, the twelve signs of the zo- diac. It is disturbing to be offered a typology whose basis is metaphorical if the metaphor is not explained" (87)
Hayden White, Metahistory: The Historical Imag- ination in Nineteenth-Century Europe (Baltimore, MD: The Johns Hopkins UP, 1973), 7-11
Roger D. Sell, Literature as Communication: The Foundations of Mediating Criticism (Amsterdam, Philadelphia: John Benjamins, 2000) 186.
I.A. Richards, summarized in Principles of Literary Criticism (London: Routledge & Kegan Paul, 1924, 1961)
F.E. Sparshott took the ab- stracting one step further in The Concept of Criticism: An Essay (Oxford: Clarendon, 1967)
"the strong influence of Professor Northrop Frye" ([v])
Willi Goetschel, Constitut- ing Critique: Kant's Writing as Critical Praxis, trans. Eric Schwab (Durham, N.C.: Duke UP, 1994)
James Collins, Inter- preting Modern Philosophy (Princeton: Princeton UP, 1972, 1975), especially on "the demand- ing text of Descartes" (53-76)
Richard Kostelanetz, "Trends in Criticism: North American Literary Critics since the Forties," Boston University Journal 25.2 (1977): 59-68, here 64

Graham Good's "The Hegemony of Theory," Uni- versity of Toronto Quarterly 65.3 (1996): 534-55
Gerald Graff, Poetic Statement and Critical Dogma (Chicago: U of Chicago P, 1970, 1980), 77-8.

The Political Unconscious: Narrative as a So- cially Symbolic Act (Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell UP, 1981), 68-74; 135-7; and passim
